content.raw:
It would be nice to get these changes into the 8.3 release, what do you think about moving the plugin and world to the examples folder for now? This way it won't be installed and we can make API breaking changes to it.

I'm thinking mostly about the use case for ServiceSim and I imagine we may want to do other tweaks to the collision shapes and surface properties, so we might use a different version of this plugin instead.
content.html:
It would be nice to get these changes into the 8.3 release, what do you think about moving the plugin and world to the examples folder for now? This way it won't be installed and we can make API breaking changes to it.

I'm thinking mostly about the use case for ServiceSim and I imagine we may want to do other tweaks to the collision shapes and surface properties, so we might use a different version of this plugin instead.

content.raw: can we not add this as a private function to the Actor class?
content.html: can we not add this as a private function to the Actor class?

content.raw: I think that should be ABI compatible, but I don't think there's much benefit since it doesn't use any class members, do you think it's worth it?
content.html: I think that should be ABI compatible, but I don't think there's much benefit since it doesn't use any class members, do you think it's worth it?

content.raw: in the past, we only did it to avoid breaking ABI so I thought we wouldn't have to do it here (for the sake of OOP). If it's done, [google's style guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Nonmember,_Static_Member,_and_Global_Functions) recommends wrapping them in an unnamed namespace.
content.html: in the past, we only did it to avoid breaking ABI so I thought we wouldn't have to do it here (for the sake of OOP). If it's done, google's style guide recommends wrapping them in an unnamed namespace.

content.raw: Ok, I'll make it a static function in case some other class may want to borrow it.
content.html: Ok, I'll make it a static function in case some other class may want to borrow it.

content.raw: Nevermind about static, just made a private one like your original suggestion: 721758b
content.html: Nevermind about static, just made a private one like your original suggestion: 721758b

content.raw: I think there is a small possibility that this breaks user code. There could be downstream users counting on the sphere-shaped collisions and doing the init trick from a plugin just like we did here.
content.html: I think there is a small possibility that this breaks user code. There could be downstream users counting on the sphere-shaped collisions and doing the init trick from a plugin just like we did here.

Is there perhaps a new way to implement the actor collision properties in Gazebo 9 that I am missing? Thank you.

content.raw:
Thanks for your quick response. I see the files you linked in Gazebo9. I
just installed ROS melodic on a new machine with ‘sudo apt-get install
ros-melodic-desktop-full’, which comes with Gazebo packages. It does not
have the actor collision plugins, nor does it have the same version of
Actor.hh on bitbucket. Is it possible that the ROS melodic download does
not contain the most recent version of Gazebo? I realize this may be out of
your jurisdiction and will just go ahead and install Gazebo from source and
see if it fixes the problem.
content.html: Thanks for your quick response. I see the files you linked in Gazebo9. I just installed ROS melodic on a new machine with ‘sudo apt-get install ros-melodic-desktop-full’, which comes with Gazebo packages. It does not have the actor collision plugins, nor does it have the same version of Actor.hh on bitbucket. Is it possible that the ROS melodic download does not contain the most recent version of Gazebo? I realize this may be out of your jurisdiction and will just go ahead and install Gazebo from source and see if it fixes the problem.
